Ian Badcoe wrote:

>>Well I actually started out by devising an indirect encoding based on a
>>genome with a tree structure. What I realised was, that without
>>something to compare against I couldn't determine if the technique was
>>better than the more simple direct encodings out there.
>>    
>>
>
>It may not be better for simple problems.  I believe the judgement 
>criterion for indirect coding will be addressing harder problems, not 
>working better on the current ones.
>  
>
Yes I agree. That's why I'm keen on finding some sufficiently 
difficult/taxing problem domains, but domains that take up as little CPU 
time as possible. The problem with most domains is that the better a 
population gets the longer it takes to evaluate, this includes domains 
such as pole balancing, board games and predator/prey. At least  with 
something like OCR (effectively a classification problem) the evaluation 
time remains constant throughout. I think this area is important because 
a lot of the work of finding good genome representations is likely to 
involve a large amount of tweaking of paramerters and the underlying 
model, so when you're running multiple experiments if you have to sit 
watching a slow run then the cycles of tweaking and re-experimenting 
will quickly become very tedious!

>>Actually, I don't know how others feel about this but I'm sometimes
>>slightly baffled at just how underdevelped this areas of AI research is
>>and that some of this work wasn't done years ago!
>>    
>>
>
>It's not just this area.  I think the problem is that to publish you have 
>to implement and test, and implementation is far more time concerning than 
>design, and testing is slower still.
>
>  
>
But isn't this the case in most areas of research? Perhaps it's just not 
percieved to be as 'cool' as biological genetics and other 'real world' 
sciences.

Colin
